questions.question: What is the correct order of disaster management steps?
questions.explanation: consequences of the disaster. Response : Actions taken to address the immediate needs and mitigate further damage. Rehab : Short for rehabilitation, involving recovery efforts and rebuilding. Mitigation : Long-term strategies to reduce the risk of future disasters. Incorrect Options: Option B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.question: The blood bag is to be disposed of in
questions.explanation: waste. This includes materials contaminated with potentially infectious substances, such as blood or other bodily fluids. Since blood bags contain blood, which is considered biomedical waste, disposing of a blood bag in a yellow bin is the correct option. Incorrect Option Option A . Red bin: The red bin is commonly used for disposing of sharps, such as needles and syringes, which pose a risk of injury or transmission of infections. Blood bags, on the other hand, typically do not fall under the category of sharps. Therefore, disposing of a blood bag in a red bin is not the appropriate option. Option C . Blue bin: The blue bin is typically used for recyclable materials, such as paper, cardboard, plastic, or glass. Blood bags are not recyclable materials, and their disposal in a blue bin is not appropriate. Option D . Black bin: The black bin is generally used for non-recyclable general waste or trash. Blood bags, being biomedical waste, should not be disposed of in the black bin. Reference: .

questions.question: Which organization is responsible for gathering and regularly publishing extensive surveys on morbidity, family planning, and vital events?
questions.explanation: Office(NSSO) headed by a Director General conducts large scale sample surveys in diverse fields throughout India. National Sample Survey Office(NSSO): Primarily data are collected through nation-wide household surveys. NSSO also collects data on rural and urban prices and plays a significant role in the improvement of crop statistics. It also maintains a frame of urban area units for use in sample surveys in urban areas. Four divisions of NSSO: Survey Design and Research Division (SDRD) Field Operations Division (FOD) Data Processing Division (DPD) Survey Coordination Division (SCD) Reference: https://www.mospi.gov.in/national-sample-survey-officensso

questions.question: A nurse got an accidental prick from a needle used for an HIV+ patient. Which single test would lead to a confirmatory diagnosis in her?
questions.explanation: INFECTION Screening tests ELISA screens for HIV antibodies (most sensitive) (Option C ruled out) Confirmatory tests Western blot - A confirmatory test confirms specific antibodies against p24 and gp41 proteins. (highly specific) (Option D) Confirmatory test for adults - qPCR for HIV1 (Option B ruled out) Confirmatory tests of infants < 1 year - HIV DNA RT-PCR Virus Isolation Direct virus testing is not standard; HIV isolation from cultured lymphocytes is costly and resource-intensive. CD4 Lymphocyte Count Most reliable predictor of HIV progression; absolute count indicates immune system health, with <200 cells/ÂµL signalling a high risk of AIDS-related infections. CD4 Lymphocyte Percentage Independent indicator of disease progression; <14% suggests a heightened risk of AIDS-related complications. HIV Viral Load Tests Measure actively replicating HIV in blood; correlate with disease progression and assess antiretroviral therapy effectiveness. Other Markers Beta-2 microglobulin (B2M) levels and p24 antigen presence indicate immune activation and viral replication, aiding disease assessment. P24 antigen tests positive in the window period (Option A ruled out) Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition Pg 400 - 401 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482145/

questions.question: A 38-year-old man visited the Suraksha clinic due to an anorectal discharge. Which of the following kits, color-coded for specific purposes, is advised for the syndromic treatment of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
questions.explanation: HIV/AIDS Control Government STI/RTI clinics, branded as "Suraksha Clinics," offer free standardized integrated STD and RTI treatment services at district-level and above healthcare facilities. Under National AIDS Control Program (NACP) Referral Centers STD Clinics at district, block, and First Referral Unit (FRU) levels act as referral centers for specialized treatment. Counselling and Condom Distribution Counselling services and high-quality condoms are provided to promote safer sexual practices. Utilizes the expertise of NGOs in providing counselling services at STD clinics. Training and strengthening existing centers Existing STD clinics in hospitals and medical colleges are strengthened with technical support, equipment, Training for medical staff to manage STDs/RTIs using a syndromic approach. Pre-packed STI/RTI Color-Coded Kits Free pre-packed kits provided to clinics, centrally procured and distributed through State AIDS Control Societies. Kit Colors and Conditions Kit 1 (Grey) Urethral discharge, anorectal discharge , and cervicitis (Option A) Kit 2 (Green) Vaginitis (Option B ruled out) Kit 3 (White) (Non-herpetic) Genital ulcers (Option C ruled out) Kit 4 (Blue) (non-herpetic) in patient allergic to penicillin Genital ulcers (Option D ruled out) Kit 5 (Red) (herpetic) Genital ulcers Kit 6 (Yellow) Lower abdominal pain (PID) Kit 7 (Black) Inguinal bubo Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition Pg 501 https://naco.gov.in/sti-rti-services

questions.question: What type of bags are used for the disposal of chemical waste?
questions.explanation: (Option A) Human anatomical waste. Animal anatomical waste. Soiled waste. Discarded or expired medicine. Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste. Chemical waste. Chemical liquid waste. Placenta. Post-operative body parts. Plaster of Paris (POP). Pathological waste. Cotton waste. Dressing materials. Beddings. Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth. Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover. Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines. Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste. Blood bag Vacutainers with blood Incineration. Plasma pyrolysis. Deep burial. Red (Option C) Contaminated waste that is recyclable. Syringe without needles. Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut. IVset. Catheters. Gloves (soiled or unsoiled). Urine bag. Dialysis kit. IVbottles. Tubing's. Bottles. Vacutainers with needle cut. Vacutainers without blood. ELISA plate and vials not containing blood samples. Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making. Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites. White (Option B) Waste Sharps Needles Syringes with fixed needles Blades Scalpers Trocar cannula Insulin pen needle Puncture proof , Leak proof, Tamper proof containers Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding or mutilation or encapsulation in metal container or cement concrete Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries or sanitary landfill or designated concrete waste sharp pit Blue Glassware or metallic body implants. Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated. Glass: Broken glass. Ampoules. Lab slide Metals: Nails. Metallic body implants. Scissors. Artificial pacemakers. Cardboard boxes with blue coloured marking or blue coloured puncture- proof and tamper-proof containers. Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving or microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling. Incorrect Options: Green (Option D) is used for general waste and not biomedical waste. Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 900

questions.question: Which compound is primarily responsible for the disinfectant properties of bleaching powder among the following options?
questions.explanation: serves as both a disinfectant and bleaching agent. When dissolved in water, it releases hypochlorous acid (HOCl) and hypochlorite ion (ClO-) as active disinfectants. Hypochlorous acid, primarily responsible for disinfection, acts as a potent oxidizing agent, effectively killing bacteria, viruses, and fungi. Incorrect Option: Hypochlorite ion (Option A): Bleaching powder releases hypochlorite ion (ClO-) when dissolved, but its disinfecting power mainly comes from HOCl, more effective due to superior antimicrobial activity than ClO-. Hydrochloric acid (Option B): Bleaching powder doesn't contain hydrochloric acid (HCl). Its disinfecting property stems from chlorine compounds, primarily hypochlorous acid (HOCl), not HCl. Chloride ion (Option D): Bleaching powder releases chloride ions (Cl-) when dissolved but disinfection is primarily from HOCl formed by hypochlorite ions reacting with water. Cl- lacks significant disinfecting properties Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 67

questions.question: What is the duration of the extended sickness benefit provided to an employee who has been diagnosed with TB?
questions.explanation: period of 2 years at 80 % of daily wages. It is provided for 34 Diseases including TB, leprosy, HIV and mental illness etc. Benefits of ESI(Employees State Insurance) Act. Medical Benefit Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity. Sickness Benefit Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner. Extended Sickness Benefit Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years. Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages. Enhanced Sickness Benefit Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilisation procedures: 14 days for tubectomy (women), 7 days for vasectomy (men). Maternity Benefit Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness: 26 weeks for childbirth, 6 weeks for miscarriage, and 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness. Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages. Disablement Benefit Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB): 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery. Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB): 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity. Dependent's Benefit Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, eligible until age 18 or earlier for married daughters. Funeral Expenses Offers a cash payment up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual. Rehabilitation Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment even after permanent disablement or retirement. They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month to avail this benefit. Rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted. Unemployment allowance For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years. Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 900

questions.question: As per the Factories Act 1948, what is the maximum number of work hours allowed per week, including any hours worked as overtime?
questions.explanation: hours. Hours of work: 48 hours per week or 9 hours per day. 60 hours per week including overtime. 4 and Â½ hours per day for adolescents. Women and adolescents can only be employed between 6 am and 7 pm. Reference: https://labour.gov.in/sites/default/files/factories_act_1948.pdf

questions.question: Which of the following bags are used for disposing of latex gloves after they have been used?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Red Used latex gloves are classified as infectious biomedical waste and should be disposed of in red bags , as per the Biomedical Waste Management Rules, 2016 . Color-Coded Waste Disposal System: Red Bag : Used for contaminated items like: Latex gloves IV tubes, catheters, syringes (without needles) Disposable PPE These items are sent for autoclaving or shredding followed by recycling. Yellow Bag : (Option A ruled out) Used for waste requiring incineration , such as: Anatomical waste Soiled dressings, bandages Pathological waste (e.g., human tissues) Blue Bag : (Option C ruled out) Used for glassware and sharp metal objects , such as: Broken ampoules Vials Metallic implants Transparent Bag : (Option D ruled out) Typically used for general waste like paper, food, or non-infectious material. Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 853

questions.question: In the case of a child presenting with pharyngitis, when a throat swab is collected and sent for culture, in which colored bin should the used swab be disposed of?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Yellow Explanation: In healthcare settings, waste disposal is categorized by color-coded bins to ensure safe and proper handling of different types of waste. Yellow bins are typically used for disposing of clinical waste that is contaminated or potentially infectious, such as used swabs, tissues, or any material that has come into contact with body fluids. In the case of a throat swab collected for culture, it would be considered infectious waste until proven otherwise, so it should be disposed of in a yellow bin . Biomedical Waste Disposal: Color Category of Waste Description Examples Yellow Infectious waste Waste that may contain pathogens and poses a risk of infection. Contaminated dressings, swabs, body fluids, soiled surgical items Red (Option A ruled out) Contaminated waste (non-infectious) Waste that has been contaminated with bodily fluids but is not infectious. Non-sharp waste like plastic, tubing, syringes (without needles), and items used in medical treatments Blue (Option D ruled out) Glass waste Waste consisting of broken glassware or other glass items. Glass vials, ampoules, broken glass containers White (Translucent) (Option C ruled out) Sharp waste Waste items that can cut or puncture, requiring careful handling. Needles, syringes with needles, scalpels, razors, and broken glass Black General or non-biomedical waste Non-hazardous waste that is not contaminated by biological or medical waste. Paper, packaging, non-infectious non-medical waste Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 852- 854

questions.question: A patient admitted following a road traffic accident has left a blood spill on the hospital floor. Which disinfectant is most appropriate for effectively decontaminating the area?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sodium hypochlorite Explanation: Sodium hypochlorite is the disinfectant of choice for cleaning blood spills on hospital floors due to its potent virucidal, bactericidal, and sporicidal properties. It effectively destroys blood-borne pathogens, including hepatitis B and C viruses and HIV, which might be present in the spilled blood. The recommended concentration for disinfecting blood spills is 1% sodium hypochlorite (10,000 ppm). Blood Spill Cleaning Protocol Step Action Details 1. PPE Wear Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Gloves, goggles/face shield, gown/apron, mask (if necessary) to protect from exposure. 2. Control the Spill Area Secure and contain the spill Alert others, prevent access, and use absorbent materials (e.g., paper towels) to contain the spill. 3. Select and Apply Disinfectant Use appropriate disinfectant Sodium hypochlorite (1%) is preferred. Apply disinfectant to the spill and allow it to sit for 10 minutes. 4. Clean the Spill Wipe the area with absorbent materials Use disposable towels or wipes to clean up the blood and dispose of them in biohazard waste. 5. Disinfect Surrounding Area Clean the surrounding floor or surfaces Mop or wipe down the surrounding area with disinfectant to ensure thorough decontamination. 6. Dispose of Contaminated Items Safely dispose of contaminated materials Place used gloves, mop heads, towels, and any contaminated materials in a biohazard waste container. 7. Remove and Dispose of PPE Safely remove PPE and dispose of it Remove gloves last, ensuring that they are turned inside out. Dispose of PPE in biohazard waste containers. 8. Wash Hands Clean hands thoroughly after cleaning Wash hands with soap and water, or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer if soap is unavailable. 9. Documentation and Reporting Record the incident and inform relevant departments Document the blood spill and cleaning procedure, and report any potential exposures to infection control. Ethyl alcohol (Option A): Alcohol is effective as a disinfectant for skin or small equipment but is not suitable for blood spills as it gets inactivated by organic matter like blood. It does not have sporicidal properties. Chlorhexidine (Option B): Chlorhexidine is primarily used for antisepsis (skin preparation before surgery or wound cleaning). It lacks activity against all viruses and is ineffective against bacterial spores. Formaldehyde (Option D): While formaldehyde is a powerful disinfectant and sterilant, it is a gas at room temperature and not practical for cleaning floors. Its application involves complex procedures and can be hazardous to humans due to its toxic and irritant nature. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11368531/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7158362/

In this case, the glove paper cover is a single-use item that is used to cover and protect gloves before use. Once the gloves are taken out and used, the paper cover becomes non-recyclable waste and should be disposed of in the black bin. ELISA plate and vials not containing blood samples. Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making. Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites. questions.question: What is the primary method of absorption of inorganic lead in industrial settings that can result in lead poisoning?

options.C: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.explanation: route of exposure and absorption of inorganic lead. This occurs when lead-containing particles become airborne, usually as a result of industrial processes such as smelting, welding, or battery manufacturing. Workers who breathe in the contaminated air can inhale these lead particles, which can then be absorbed into the bloodstream through the respiratory system. Incorrect Options: Absorption through skin (Option A): While it is true that lead can be absorbed through the skin, it is not the most common mode of absorption in industrial settings. Ingestion of contaminated food and water (Option C): Contaminated food and water can cause lead exposure and poisoning, notably in residential or environmental contexts, but it's not the primary route of absorption in industrial settings. Contaminated hands (Option D): While contact with contaminated hands can contribute to lead exposure, it is not the most common mode of absorption in industrial settings. Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 996

questions.question: What is the most frequent association of lung malignancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Asbestosis Asbestosis is strongly associated with lung malignancy, particularly bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma. Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung . Past exposure to asbestos is specifically indicated by pleural plaques on chest radiographs, which are characterized by either thickening or calcification along the parietal pleura, particularly along the lower lung fields. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity. Complications include carcinoma of lung and mesothelioma . Silicosis (Option B): Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, which increases the risk of tuberculosis and may slightly elevate the risk of lung cancer. However, the association with lung malignancy is much weaker compared to asbestosis. Bagassosis (Option C): Bagassosis is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to sugarcane bagasse dust. It does not have a known association with lung malignancy. Byssinosis (Option D): Byssinosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling cotton, flax, or hemp dust. It primarily leads to chronic obstructive airway disease and is not associated with lung cancer. Reference: Harrisonâs Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2168 Davidsonâs Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 615

questions.question: Arrange the order of the Disaster management cycle
questions.explanation: fundamental aspects of disaster management: Disaster impact: Involves disaster response and relief. Disaster preparedness: It is the proper equipment of the country to manage disasters. Disaster mitigation: Preventing the hazard from becoming a disaster. Reference: Park 27e, pg no:923 (including image)

questions.question: Patients requiring immediate life-threatening care are categorized under which of the following triages?
questions.explanation: attention to save their lives. This includes conditions such as severe bleeding, major trauma, or cardiac arrest. Incorrect Options: Option B â Yellow: The yellow category in triage is for patients who need urgent care but are not immediately life-threatening. Option C - Green: The green category in triage is for patients with minor injuries who can wait for treatment. Option D â Black: The black category in triage is for patients who are deceased or whose injuries are so severe that survival is unlikely. Reference: .

questions.question: Which pneumoconiosis is caused by exposure to cotton dust?
questions.explanation: flax, or hemp dust, primarily in the textile manufacturing industry. Bagassosis (Option B): an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling bagasse (sugarcane dust). Caused by Thermoactinomyces sacchari with ymptoms include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, slight fever, and acute diffuse bronchiolitis. Chest X-ray may show lung mottling or shadowing and impaired pulmonary function. Anthracosis or Coal Workers' Pneumoconiosis (aka "black lung disease" ) (Option C) : This condition affects workers in coal mining due to inhalation of coal dust. Silicosis (Option D): Often occurs in workers exposed to silica dust in industries like mining and quarrying. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 472

questions.question: What is the recommended area per worker in a factory, considering that any height above a specified limit is not taken into account?
questions.explanation: recommended minimum space per worker is 500 cubic feet. This regulation is in place to ensure that workers have enough space to work comfortably and safely, reducing the risk of accidents and health issues that can arise from overcrowding. Factory Act Definition An establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used or 20 or more workers where power is not used. Applicability Applies to all of India and covers all factories, including perennial and seasonal factories. Age Restrictions Prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age. 15-18 year olds need fitness certificate for factory work from a certified surgeon Hours of Work Work limited to 48 hours/week or 9 hours/day; max 60 hours/week with overtime. Adolescents: max 4.5 hours/day. Women and adolescents: work hours 6 am to 7 pm. Leave Grants 1 day of leave per 15 days of work for adolescents 1 day per 30 days of work for adults. Permits accumulation of leaves up to 40 days for adolescents and 30 days for adults. Health & Safety Mandates a minimum of 500 cubic feet of space per worker. Requires 1 safety officer per 1000 workers. Welfare Stipulates 1 welfare officer per 500 workers, 1 canteen per 250 workers, and 1 crÃ¨che per 30 women workers. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 472 labour.gov.in/sites/default/files/factories_act_1948.pdf

questions.question: Heart of sewage disposal plant:
questions.explanation: this stage, the effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is subjected to aerobic oxidation, promoting the growth of microorganisms that break down organic pollutants in the sewage. Sewage treatment plant: Primary treatment involves screening, a grit chamber, and a plain sedimentation tank. The process is anaerobic digestion. Secondary treatment involves either the trickling filter or the activated sludge process. The process involves aerobic oxidation The activated sludge process is an easier method as it requires less process and involves an aeration tank. This process is essential for effectively reducing biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and improving the quality of the treated effluent. Trickling filter is a biological filter that uses microorganisms to remove organic matter and nitrogen from wastewater . Sedimentation tank is stage three of sewage treatment. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are components of the sewage treatment plant, but they are less essential as compared to the aeration tank. Reference: Parkâs textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th edition, page: 889

questions.question: Which phases of the disaster cycle can be included in the recovery phase (multiple choice)? Response Rehabilitation Mitigation Preparedness
questions.explanation: decisions, organizations to implement policies, strategies to lessen the impact of natural or man-made hazards. Disaster management cycle: The three fundamental aspects of disaster management: Disaster impact: Involves disaster response and relief. Disaster preparedness: It is the proper equipment of the country to manage disasters. Disaster mitigation: Preventing the hazard from becoming a disaster. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 923

questions.question: Which benefit does a patient receive when seeking treatment at an ESI hospital under the ESI Act?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Medical benefit When seeking treatment at an ESI hospital , the primary benefit received is medical care , falling under the Medical Benefit category. Benefits of ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act Medical Benefit Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity. Sickness Benefit (Option A) Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner. Extended Sickness Benefit Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years. Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages. Enhanced Sickness Benefit Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilization procedures: 14 days for tubectomy (women), 7 days for vasectomy (men). Maternity Benefit (Option C) Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness: 26 weeks for childbirth, 6 weeks for miscarriage, and 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness. Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages. Disablement Benefit Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB): 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery. Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB): 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity. Dependent's Benefit (Option D) Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, and they are eligible until age 18. If the daughter marries before 18, the benefit is withdrawn. Funeral Expenses It offers a cash payment of up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual. Rehabilitation Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement. They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month for this benefit. A rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted. Unemployment allowance For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 943, 944 https://www.esic.gov.in/benefits https://www.esic.gov.in/information-benefits https://www.indiacode.nic.in/handle/123456789/1441?view_type=browse&sam_handle=123456789/1362

questions.question: What type of waste in the following bag is disposed of through incineration?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Yellow Used for disposing of infectious waste and items contaminated with blood, body fluids, or human tissue. This includes pathological waste, soiled dressings, bandages, and animal anatomical waste. These items are incinerated to prevent infection and reduce contamination risk. Colour Waste Type Type of bag or container to be used Method of disposal Yellow All infectious waste. Human anatomical waste. Animal anatomical waste Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags ). Expired or discarded medicines Chemical waste. Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste. Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Incineration Plasma pyrolysis Deep burial Red (Option B) Contaminated waste (recyclable) : Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags , syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves. Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill). Blue (Option C) Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste. Metallic body implants . Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings. Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling. White Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. Puncture proof and leak proof containers. Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation. Black bags (Option D): are typically managed through landfill or other standard waste management methods. Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 918 - 920

questions.question: What are the potential health risks faced by workers in a sugarcane factory?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Bagassosis Bagassosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of moldy sugarcane dust. Sugarcane bagasse is the fibrous residue left after extracting juice from sugarcane, and it can become moldy in certain conditions. Workers in sugarcane factories who handle or process bagasse are at risk of developing bagassosis due to inhalation of mold spores. Bagassosis Caused by - Inhalation of sugar cane fibers, cardboard industry and paper industry. Infested by a fungus known Thermoactinomyces sacchari. Reported in India by two people- Ganguly and Pal. X-ray findings: Mottling of lung fields. Bagasse control: Keep the moisture content more than 20% and also spray the bagasse with 2% propionic acid. Anthracosis (Option A): is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of coal dust. Siderosis (Option B): is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of iron dust or particles. Byssinosis (Option D): also known as "brown lung disease," is primarily associated with exposure to dust from textile materials such as cotton, flax, or hemp. Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 933 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/p mc/articles/PMC7724370/#:~:text=Bird%20Fancier's%20Lung%20is%20a,common%20causes%20of%20hypersen sitivity%20pneumonitis.

questions.question: As per the guidelines for disposing of biomedical waste, what color bag should be used to discard used cotton swabs?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Yellow As per biomedical waste management guidelines, used cotton swabs, which are categorized as infectious waste contaminated with body fluids, should be disposed of in yellow bags . Colour Waste Type Type of bag or container to be used Method of disposal Yellow All infectious waste. Human anatomical waste. Animal anatomical waste Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags ). Expired or discarded medicines Chemical waste. Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste. Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Incineration Plasma pyrolysis Deep burial Red Contaminated waste (recyclable) : Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags , syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves. Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill). Blue Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste. Metallic body implants . Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings. Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling. White Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. Puncture proof and leak proof containers. Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation. Reference: Parkâs Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 918 - 920

questions.question: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is: Correct Answer: Unknown Explanation: Correct Answer D - 1 acre For a population of 10,000, a 2-meter-deep trench is dug, and 1 acre of land is required Category Details Methods of Refuse Disposal 1. Dumping: Unsatisfactory; becomes a nuisance. 2. Controlled Tipping (Sanitary Landfill): Most satisfactory; achieved via trench, ramp, and area methods. Modified Sanitary Landfill: Compacting and covering are done once or twice a week Methods of controlled tipping a. Trench Method: Used on level ground. Most important method Dug on level ground, 2-3 meters deep and 4-12 meters wide. For a population of 10,000, a 2-meter-deep trench requires 1 acre of land. b. Ramp Method: For moderately sloping terrain c. Area Method: Requires supplemental earth, used in depressions or quarries. Technique in controlled tipping Physical, chemical, and bacteriological changes occur in buried refuse. Temperature rises to 60Â°C after 7 days, killing pathogens, followed by decomposition. Organic matter decomposes into innocuous soil in 4-6 months, used as manure Cooling occurs within 2-3 weeks. Final product: Manure used in farming. Reference: https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3292&context=roadschool#:~:text=Sanitary%2 0landfill%20is%20the%20most,have%20an%20air%20pollution%20problem .
Please select the appropriate sequence of actions for disaster management.

options.A: Disaster impact â Mitigation â Rehabilitation â Response
options.B: Disaster impact â Responseâ Rehabilitation â Mitigation
options.C: Rehabilitation â Response â Disaster Impact â Mitigation
options.D: Response â Disaster impact â Mitigation â Rehabilitation

questions.explanation: with the occurrence of a damaging event. Response: Immediate actions include search and rescue, medical care, and evacuation. Rehabilitation: Focuses on restoring services and infrastructure. Mitigation: Long-term efforts to reduce future disaster impact through planning and infrastructure improvements. Incorrect Options : A, C & D Reference: .

questions.question: The symbol shown in the image depicts
questions.explanation: radiation hazards. It is the international symbol for ionizing radiation, recognized globally to warn individuals about the presence of radioactive materials or sources. The symbol consists of three interconnected triangles forming a trefoil shape with a central dot, representing the radiation source. Incorrect Options : Option A . Cytotoxic waste: The symbol for cytotoxic waste typically features the text "Cytotoxic" along with a specific symbol, which differs from the one shown in the image. Option B . Biomedical waste: The symbol for biomedical waste usually depicts a combination of the universal biohazard symbol and additional text or symbols to indicate the type of waste. Option D . Biohazard: The biohazard symbol features a universal symbol of a solid black biohazardous material on a contrasting orange background. Reference: .

questions.question: What should you do immediately if you accidentally spill some blood on the floor while collecting samples?

options.A: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.explanation: follow proper infection control measures to minimize the risk of contamination and transmission of bloodborne pathogens.: Incorrect Options: Option A . Call the infection control team of the hospital: Immediate action to clean up is crucial to prevent accidents and exposure while involving the infection control team is vital for significant incidents Option B . Mop it: Mopping alone may not be sufficient for cleaning a blood spill, as it may spread the blood and increase the risk of contamination. Option C . Cover it with 1% sodium hypochlorite:. While using a disinfectant is important, covering the spill alone may not be sufficient. The spill needs to be cleaned up first before applying the disinfectant. Reference: .

questions.question: Please arrange the following coloured dustbins according to the type of biomedical waste they are meant for. Column A Column B Catheter Torn registration forms Expired vaccine Antibiotic bottle A. Black B. Red C. Blue D. Yellow E. White
questions.explanation: should be disposed of in a puncture-resistant blue container. Torn registration forms : Torn registration forms are typically disposed of in black coloured general waste bins. Expired vaccine: Expired vaccines, categorized as pharmaceutical waste, should be disposed of in designated yellow containers for pharmaceutical waste. Antibiotic bottle: Empty antibiotic bottles are generally recyclable and can be disposed of in red bins. Incorrect Options: Options A, B & D are incorrect matches. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the phase(s) of the disaster cycle that occurs before the impact of the disaster?
questions.explanation: used in disaster management to understand and address the various stages of a disaster. "Mitigation and preparedness" phases occur before the actual impact of a disaster. Disaster mitigation aims to reduce risks and vulnerabilities through activities like risk assessment and preventive measures. Preparedness involves planning, training, and stockpiling supplies for effective disaster response. Incorrect Options: Option A. Disaster response: This phase occurs during and immediately after a disaster when emergency response efforts are initiated. Option B. Medical relief and rehabilitation: This phase is part of the recovery phase and involves providing medical assistance and rehabilitation services to affected individuals. Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is a phase of the disaster cycle that occurs after the immediate response and focuses on restoring and rebuilding the affected areas.

questions.question: Which of the options listed below pertains to the field of Disaster management, which deals with the mitigation and response to abrupt, devastating incidents that significantly impede the operations of a community or society, resulting in human, material, and economic or environmental consequences?
questions.explanation: typically responsible for disaster management in many countries. This ministry oversees and coordinates various aspects of disaster management, including disaster response, relief operations, and coordination with other relevant agencies and stakeholders. Incorrect Options : Option A. Ministry of Health: The Ministry of Health is vital in public health emergencies, but it may not lead overall disaster management. Option B. Ministry of HRD: The Ministry of HRD focuses on education and human resource development, not necessarily disaster management. Option D. Ministry of Agriculture: The Ministry of Agriculture focuses on agricultural policies and food security, important during disasters, but may not lead disaster management.

questions.question: Human anatomical wastes are disposed of in the ____ BMW category?
questions.explanation: are disposed of in the yellow BMW category. The yellow bag is used to dispose of infectious or pathological waste, such as anatomical waste that includes human tissues, organs, body fluids, and body parts. Incorrect Options: Option A - Red: The red bag is used to dispose of contaminated waste that is recyclable. Option C - White: The white bag is used to dispose of waste sharps. Option D - Blue: The blue bag is used to dispose of glassware or metallic body implants. Reference: .

questions.question: How are cytotoxic and expired drugs typically disposed of?
questions.explanation: controlled environment. Incineration is an effective method for the disposal of cytotoxic drugs, which are hazardous due to their potential toxicity. It ensures that the drugs are completely destroyed, reducing the risk of environmental contamination and potential harm to human health. Incorrect Options Option A: Dumping- Dumping, or simply discarding drugs, is not an appropriate method for disposing of cytotoxic and expired drugs. Option B: Autoclave-Autoclaving sterilizes by high heat and pressure, effective for lab waste and medical gear, but not ideal for disposing of cytotoxic drugs or expired medications. Option D: Chemical disinfection- Chemical disinfection kills microbes on surfaces or in liquids but isn't suitable for disposing of cytotoxic or expired drugs.

questions.question: Which of the statements below is correct regarding the Factories Act?

options.A: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
options.B: A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
options.C: The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
options.D: A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.explanation: is true and in line with the provisions of the Factories Act. The Act prohibits the employment of children below the age of 14 in any factory. Incorrect Options: Option B: A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM- The Act states that they should not be allowed to work between 7 PM and 6 AM. Option C: The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week- As per the Act, an adult worker should not be required to work more than 48 hours in a week. Option D: A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day- The Factories Act limits working hours for children aged 15 to 18 to a maximum of 4.5 hours per day and 9 hours in any continuous period, including breaks.

questions.question: What is the likelihood of genetic diseases occurring in a consanguineous marriage between first cousins?
questions.explanation: individuals, such as first cousins. When individuals who share a significant amount of genetic material have children together, there is an increased risk in offspring of traits controlled by recessive genes and those determined by polygenes. The estimated risk is generally considered to be in the range of 4-8%. Incorrect Options: Options A, C & D are incorrect

questions.question: During disaster management, triage is implemented to ensure that casualties receive appropriate treatment. Which statement accurately describes the triage process conducted at the disaster site?

options.B: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
options.C: Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
options.D: Most commonly used system is three color code system

questions.explanation: limited resources wisely, prioritizing care based on severity. "Moribund" describes patients in critical condition with slim survival chances despite treatment. They may get lower priority due to resource constraints, with focus on those likely to benefit most from immediate help. Incorrect Options: Option A. First come first treated basis: Triage in disasters doesn't follow "first come, first served." Instead, it prioritizes based on severity, ensuring critical cases get immediate attention. Option B. Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority: Green labels are for minor injuries or illnesses, indicating patients who can wait for medical attention and don't need immediate care or transport. Option D. Most commonly used system is a three-color code system: Triage systems vary globally and often use more than three colors for coding.

questions.question: Bagassosis occurs with:
questions.explanation: inhalation of dust or aerosols containing thermophilic actinomycetes from sugarcane fibers. Bagasse is the fibrous residue left after extracting juice from sugarcane. Workers involved in handling or processing sugarcane, such as in sugar mills or paper mills, may be at risk of developing bagassosis if they inhale the airborne particles containing the actinomycetes. Incorrect options Option A. Silica fibers: Silica exposure can cause various lung diseases, such as silicosis, when inhaled in significant amounts over an extended period. However, silica fibers are not specifically associated with bagassosis. Option B. Carbon particles: Carbon particles can have respiratory effects. However, they are not directly linked to bagassosis. Option D . Cotton: Cotton dust exposure is associated with a respiratory condition known as byssinosis or "brown lung disease."

questions.question: Which disease is frequently reported in the aftermath of Gujarat's recent massive earthquake disaster, resulting in loss of life and immense suffering?
questions.explanation: there can be disruptions in water supply, sanitation systems, and hygiene practices, leading to an increased risk of gastrointestinal infections.. The conditions after a disaster, such as contaminated water sources or poor sanitation, can contribute to the spread of pathogens that cause gastroenteritis. Incorrect Options: Option B . Pneumonia: While pneumonia can occur after a disaster, it is not typically the most commonly reported disease in the post-disaster period.. Option C . Leptospirosis: Leptospirosis is more commonly associated with flooding or situations where there is extensive water contamination, such as in tropical regions or areas with poor sanitation.. Option D . Malnutrition:. While malnutrition can be a significant concern in post-disaster situations, it is not a specific disease.

questions.question: Inertization is:

options.A: Reducing organic and combustible waste to inorganic

questions.explanation: converting biomedical waste into a non-harmful or inert form. The process involves mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal, inorder to minimize the risk of toxic substances contained in the wastes migrating into the surface water or groundwater. Incorrect Options: Option A : "Reducing organic and combustible waste to inorganic" describes the process of incineration, not inertization. Option B : "Burning biomedical waste" Burning, or incineration, can be a method of treating biomedical waste, but it is not synonymous with inertization. Option D : "To avoid water contamination" Inertization focuses on rendering biomedical waste non-harmful rather than specifically targeting water contamination.

questions.question: In Disaster management, what is the term used when patients are classified based on their likelihood of survival?
questions.explanation: of their medical needs and their chances of survival. The main objective of triage is to ensure that limited resources are allocated to those patients who are most in need and have the highest chances of survival. Patients are typically categorized into different triage categories, such as immediate, delayed, minimal, or expectant, depending on the severity of their injuries or illnesses. Incorrect Options : Option B: Tagging- Tagging refers to the process of identifying and labeling patients or individuals during a disaster or mass casualty incident. Option C: Mitigation- Mitigation refers to measures taken to minimize or prevent the impact of disasters or reduce their severity. Option D: Surge capacity- Surge capacity refers to the ability of healthcare systems to expand their resources and capabilities to accommodate a sudden influx of patients during a disaster or emergency.

questions.question: Anthracosis is caused by
questions.explanation: caused by the inhalation and deposition of coal dust particles in the lungs. It commonly affects individuals who are exposed to coal dust over a prolonged period, such as coal miners, workers in coal-fired industries, and individuals living in areas with high levels of coal dust pollution. Incorrect Options: Option a. Silica:. Prolonged inhalation of silica dust can lead to a lung disease called silicosis.. Option c. Asbestos:. Inhalation of asbestos fibers can cause lung diseases, including asbestosis and mesothelioma. Anthracosis is unrelated to asbestos exposure. Option d. Sugar cane: Individuals working in the sugar cane industry may be exposed to other respiratory hazards, such as dust and mold, which can lead to respiratory conditions.

questions.question: In which bag should recyclable tubing and catheters be placed?
questions.explanation: for the disposal of potentially infectious or biohazardous waste. This includes items contaminated with blood, bodily fluids, or other potentially infectious materials. Examples of waste that should be placed in the red bag include used needles, blood-soaked dressings, and disposable tubing or catheters. Incorrect Options: Option B: Blue bag- The blue bag is typically used for the disposal of Glass bottles, glass ampoules and injection vials. Option C: Yellow bag- The yellow bag is used for the disposal of hazardous or chemical waste. This includes cytotoxic waste, expired medicine and radioactive substance. Option D: White box- The white bag is commonly used for the disposal of used needles, scalpel blades, cannula, lancets and broken glass slides. Reference: .

questions.question: Rearrange the following options related to the management of biomedical waste: Column A Column B Yellow Red Blue White translucent Glassware Scalpel blade Chemical waste Syringe
questions.explanation: White translucent B. Scalpel blade Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D are incorrect Reference: Ref: Parkâs textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: In the context of biomedical waste disposal, which type of waste is discarded in a yellow bag?
questions.explanation: including blood-soaked items such as blood bags, blood-stained bandages, and cotton swabs. Blood bags contain blood and blood components, which may pose a significant risk of infection if not disposed of correctly. Incorrect Options: Option b : Gloves - Gloves are non-infectious waste and are disposed of in a Red bag. Solid contaminated recyclable waste. Option c: Sharps - Disposed in White box. Sharps are disposed of in a puncture-resistant container labeled with the biohazard symbol. Option d: Urine bag - Urine bags contain human waste, and is disposed of in a red bag. Reference: .

questions.question: What is used to clean up blood spills in the operation theater?
questions.explanation: including viruses, bacteria, and fungi, chlorine compounds, such as sodium hypochlorite (bleach), are typically used to clean up blood spills in operating rooms. Strong oxidizing properties of chlorine compounds aid in the destruction of microorganisms and the breakdown of organic matter, including blood. Incorrect Options : Option b: Phenolic compounds are not effective as chlorine compounds as disinfectants. Option c : QAC (Quaternary ammonium compounds) are also used as a disinfectant for cleaning blood spills in operation theaters but are not as effective as chlorine compounds. Option d: Alcoholic compounds can be used for cleaning blood spills, but they are not effective as chlorine compounds for disinfection.
